4. What did the pilot tell the writer to look at?
5. What is the name of the fast plane?
6. How long was the flight? 
7. What did Dario do after they landed?

**Simplified Text:**

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you have seen polar bears in a nature show, he may have filmed them. He likes it very cold, about -18C. Allan studied marine biology and was a diver. Diving was his first love, and he learned how to survive in cold places.

His big chance came when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where he was working. He helped the crew find good places to film. After two days, he realized he loved being a wildlife cameraman. He could travel, have adventures, and dive underwater.

Now, he is a famous cameraman and has worked on many wildlife TV shows. When he started 35 years ago, not many people had been to Antarctica. There were people who filmed coral, elephants, and chimpanzees. Allan became known as the "cold man." He found many amazing things to film.

When he started, the camera technology was very simple. It is easier to film today. In the past, if you filmed something, you had to remember it. Now, with digital cameras, you can see what you filmed right away. Before, you had to think about what to film next. Film was expensive, but now you can take many videos.

Allan has a lot of experience in cold places. He knows how to work in the cold. He has spent a lot of time on sea ice. He does get cold toes, but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes.

Allan says wildlife filming has many successes, but also mistakes. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes, but he could not tell which birds they were. Recently, he got permission to film in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean. This place is home to polar bears and is very dangerous. In April, it is usually -32C, and the wind is strong. Carrying cameras in deep snow is hard. 

After walking for five hours a day and watching polar bear dens for 23 days, Allan saw only one mother bear and her cub. On the 24th day, he felt like he was in the bear world. He waited and watched. After five hours, he saw a quick glimpse of a bear. The camera was ready, and he looked through the viewfinder. He saw a black nose, then a big head, and soon the bear was resting in front of the hole. She looked at him but did not care. Then she slid down the slope, and two cubs appeared. It was their first time seeing the world.

Now, Allan wants to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic. He wants to talk to the people who live there and see how it affects them. He believes he can make a great documentary.

**Simplified Text:**

In 2004, Pen Hadow was the first person to walk to the North Pole alone. He did not get help on the way. He had to swim in very cold water and fight against frostbite and polar bears. Eight months later, he also went to the South Pole. Now, he is back in the Arctic. He is getting ready for a new trip that is very important. 

Pen and two friends will walk for three months, covering 1,000 kilometers to the North Pole. They will measure the ice. No one has done this before, and the information will help scientists understand global warming. 

When he was a child, Pen had a nanny who worked for a famous polar explorer. She made him strong by sending him outside in bad weather with few clothes. His father also loved adventures in the cold. Pen is married to Mary, who loves the outdoors too. She helps him with his polar guide business. Mary says she worries more about him when he is at home because he thinks about the Arctic.

Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. He finds it hard to be away from them. Last time he left, he told his son to take care of his mother and sister. His son took this very seriously and worried a lot. Pen thinks it was not fair to say that. This time, he will not contact them much while he is in the Arctic because he does not want to remind them how far away he is.

Before he leaves, he is getting ready and checking his equipment. He says it is hard to fix things on the ice. He will be with Ann Daniels, a famous polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, a photographer. They will have a team of six people to help them.

Pen is also thinking about his age. He will be 47 soon and feels he has not trained enough. He is worried about what he will do on the trip. He believes this mission is important because it will help scientists and many people understand what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. He feels that their skills are now very useful.

Text: "I took a year off. What would I do? Being an Olympian is special. I could write, work on TV, and talk to businesses and schools. This was fun, but I wanted to compete again. I wanted to stay fit to try for the Olympics if I felt like it. So, I joined marathons and triathlons. But then, I remembered Ben Fogle’s invitation: 'Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?' I love rowing and the feeling of the boat in the water. I missed it, but I was not ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some competition. I asked my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they were not excited. I knew if I joined, I would want to win. But rowing with Ben might not be the best chance to win. However, being an underdog without pressure was interesting. I contacted Ben. He was going to join the race and had found the money for the entry fee and a boat. This made the race real. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000, which is a lot of money. We thought we had a good chance, but it would take work. I also had to think about losing money because I would be away from home. Speaking at business events is a good way to earn money after being a sportsman. It feels nice that people want to hear me speak. But I find it hard to talk about my past without a new goal. Joining the race would mean I was doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure. One big lesson was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. Training for the Olympics was hard, but it was simple. I trained a lot, but I had a plan, doctors, and dieticians. I worried about what people would think of me racing with a TV presenter. I thought it might look like I just wanted to be on TV. But my worries went away as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is not just about rowing; it is also about the mind. Ben had done tough challenges, but he could not row well. I was surprised by how little he knew about rowing, and he was surprised by my honesty. I could have been more patient, but I needed to tell him how much he needed to improve. I should have known this would be his level when I agreed to race with him."

**Simplified Text:**

A little over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in Finland. I was 26 years old and wanted a change. I dreamed of cold, snowy places because I was tired of busy London. I found a small company run by Anna and Pasi in Finnish Lapland. They hired me as a husky dog handler for the winter season. From December to February, many tourists come to ride sleds pulled by huskies on the snow. The company started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. They also have a second place called the 'wilderness farm,' which is simple and does not have running water.

I could work with them for three months. They told me the work is hard and the hours are long. I started to pack my things. 

**November 6, London**  
On my flight, I looked at a page with pictures of more than 100 huskies. I needed to remember their names, but I felt nervous. I looked out of the window instead. I thought about how winter was coming and rivers were freezing.

**November 7, Helsinki and Hetta**  
The bus ride north was what I wanted. We drove through dark forests with snow on the trees. We stopped for reindeer on the road. I arrived at the farm at night. Anna gave me boots and sent me outside into the cold. She asked if I wanted to start working right away. I followed the sound of barking and found the dogs. They were very excited. I tried to introduce myself, but everyone was busy. I petted one of the quieter dogs. Then someone told me to get in the sled, and we started moving into the dark with a headlamp.

**November 15, Hetta**  
I learned how to be a husky guide quickly, but first, Anna asked me if I was useful. I didn’t know what to say. I had never driven a snowmobile or used an axe. But I had a driving license, and that made me feel better. 

I learned the basics of dog-sledding fast: lean into the corners, use both feet to stop, and hold the handlebar tight. But other tasks were hard. For example, water for the dogs would freeze quickly, so we made a 'soup' of meat in hot water for them. By the end of my first week, I was tired and my muscles hurt from pulling heavy sleds. But I felt proud. I told my friends, "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a saw. In the snow!"

Text: 

One day, Paula Radcliffe ran very fast in a marathon. When she finished, many reporters came to talk to her. They said her time was so good that she could run in the men's marathon in Paris. The reporters asked her about emu oil, a special oil that helps heal injuries. Cathy Freeman, an Olympic champion, told her to use it after Radcliffe had an accident while training.

Radcliffe said she did not think much about her big win at first. She felt it was just what she was supposed to do that day. She and her team believed in no limits. During the race, her husband Gary and her physiotherapist Gerard were in a car, listening to the race on the radio. After 16 kilometers, her agent worried that she might not keep up her fast pace. Gerard was angry about this because he knew how fit she was.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe thought she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes. She had already run 41 kilometers very fast, but she still ran the last part in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." The race director, Dave Bedford, said he never thought anyone would run that fast again. Radcliffe thought she would come back and do it next year, but that did not happen.

After the race, everyone wanted to know how she won against very skilled runners from East Africa. Gerard worked with Radcliffe a lot, helping her with her training. He said she could take a lot of pain and worked very hard. He traveled 13 hours to see her, and when he arrived, her husband said, "Gerard, you're late, Paula is waiting." There was no time for tea; she wanted to start training right away.

Gerard spent so much time with Radcliffe that other athletes were unhappy. When asked why no one has run as fast as her, Radcliffe said she trained hard, but some people are more talented. She thought Mary Keitany, a two-time London marathon winner, could do it. Radcliffe believed that some runners focus more on racing each other than on their own best times.

She explained that she always pushed herself to run hard, even when she was winning. Radcliffe did not know it then, but that marathon was the best time of her career. She never ran that fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

Text: 

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, started, I was nervous. I did not know if people would like it. There was a lot of talk about a new way of cooking in Britain. I thought we made a good show that was different. I was happy and scared when I watched the first episode. I did not need to worry. The show was successful, and I made other projects, including a book about my restaurant. 

In each project, I felt like I was on a journey. I wrote several books called ‘Perfection’, and each book went with a TV show. In these shows, I traveled to meet special people. One man made golden pasta that tasted amazing. These people worked hard for many years to reach their idea of perfection. 

Perfection means different things to different people. Choosing which dishes to show was hard. I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was not included. I could hear them asking, “Where is steak and kidney pie? Where is bread and butter pudding?” But after a long meeting, my team and I made a list that had something for everyone. 

I believe everyone has their own idea of perfection based on their feelings and memories. Even though the book is called ‘Perfection’, I knew the recipes were not the only way to cook. I used my skills and talked to many people to find out what makes these dishes good. 

The dictionary says ‘perfection’ means being perfect, but it also means trying new ideas and improving them. The TV show let me explore many foods and places I had never seen before. I was excited to learn about food and memories because I started my career in the same way. 

I traveled to find the best ingredients. I had many adventures, like visiting a factory that used the wrong tomatoes and a dairy farm that was not good enough for filming. I even milked a cow by hand and made ice cream with dry ice. I cooked chicken in a hospital machine and almost burned my house trying to make a real Neapolitan pizza.

Text: 

We were far from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and went off the road into a field. It stopped moving. John got out and looked at the engine. He stood there for a long time with his hands in his pockets. He looked confused. “I don’t know what I’m doing,” he said, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried. “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field was big. There was only grass and some flowers, like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I said too, because I wanted to agree with Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John walk away to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Tell us a story.” So I told them about two birds I heard talking before we left London. I told them what the birds talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. I felt sad. “I do.” But I didn’t sound sure. “Liar,” Bea said. I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? I wanted to ask Mum, but she was asleep in the sun. 

John came back with three Moroccan boys. They helped us push the van to a hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys waved and smiled at her. We followed John into a café. It was not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea was sweet and made from mint leaves. Mum looked at the pot. “It’s like syrup,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked at the engine. “It’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said when it got dark. Mum took blankets out onto the road. She made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on the ground. “I will have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said. 

Later, we sat in a truck watching our van being pulled behind. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I wondered how we would get home now that our van had to be pulled. I thought it might be easier to take a boat to London. Then I fell asleep.

Text: 

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel. She was talking to two other pianists. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from Europe. Lucy did not know the girl’s name well because it was loud. They were both older than Lucy. They spoke English well. They talked about the music they played and where they had traveled.

“I think I’m going to Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy said. Tanglewood is a famous music festival. Lucy did not really want to go there. She was busy with concerts and competitions. She missed a lot of school and was not in school anymore. She learned music with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 

Lucy did not want to come to the Prague Festival. Only fifteen pianists her age could come from all over the world. Lucy was one of them. Her dad bought her a nice necklace to celebrate. Her little brother, Gus, wanted to be in the festival one day. Lucy’s teacher, Grace, took her out for dinner to talk about music.

Lucy did not apply to the festival. Her mom filled out the form and sent a CD. “I didn’t want you to be sad if you didn’t get in,” her mom said. Lucy thought her mom did not want her to say no. 

The guy from Tokyo asked, “How old are you?” 

“Fifteen,” Lucy replied. The girl said, “Wow.” Lucy did not mean to show off. It was hard to know when to share and when to brag. 

“Have you ever been to Japan?” the guy asked. 

“Once, when I was eight,” Lucy said. 

Then, Lucy’s grandfather came to her. “Lucy, let me introduce you to someone,” he said. He took her away from the conversation. “Don’t be too friendly with the competition,” he added. 

“They are not the competition,” Lucy said. 

“Everyone is the competition,” her grandfather replied. He took her around the room to meet important people. Lucy smiled and nodded but did not understand everything.

In the elevator, her grandfather said, “You did well, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This festival is important, and people know you.” Lucy liked that. She liked being someone special. But at school, her friends did not care about her music. Even her best friend, Reyna, did not know how good she was. But here, at the festival, Lucy felt important.

Text: 

“Dad said, ‘You spend too much time online. You need to go outside.’ I wanted to know more, so I read what experts say. They say it is interesting. Many teenagers who use social media have real friends, feel good about themselves, and learn important skills for the digital world.

Simon Miles, an expert, says social media is a big part of growing up today. Teenagers use it all the time, like a youth club. It helps them share jokes and talk about their lives. Jim Matthews, another expert, says social media helps teenagers find their identity and deal with problems with friends.

Professor Keith Davidson says that when you are a teenager, you ask, “Who am I?” Social media can help you learn about yourself. You can share your favorite music or sports and see how others think. He says that people who use social media are not selfish. It can be easier to talk online than in person, especially for shy people.

Professor Andrew Phillips studies how young people use social media. He thinks it helps quiet people with special interests connect with others. If you like a certain type of music and only a few people in your school do too, you can find friends online who like it too.

Pauline White, an expert in digital education, says young people can find new interests online and create their own content. She believes social media helps teenagers be creative. They can make videos, podcasts, and blogs. Photo-sharing sites help photographers learn and share their work. This can help them get jobs in the future.

Every business uses social media to sell things. If you have many friends online, they can be customers for your product. Teenagers who use social media creatively will benefit when they grow up and work, says Matthews. He believes working together online is an important skill for the future.”

Text: 

When people think of a family vacation, they may not think of a long trip across many states in the US and Canada. But my parents wanted to have a fun family trip this summer. My dad wanted to plan a trip for us to spend time together. My brother and I were not very excited about it.

In mid-June, we packed our car with bags and food. I was happy but also worried about being with my family for two weeks. We started our big road trip. We left our big house and drove a long way. I wondered what would happen on this trip.

We drove west through Oklahoma. We had some adventures. One night, we stopped in Oklahoma and saw many stars in the sky. We learned that cows can cross the road first! The next day, we woke up early and drove again. We saw deserts and then mountains. Each day was different, but they all felt similar.

We visited the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. It smelled funny there. We learned that some roads are not good for regular cars. We saw many old and new things on our trip. Sometimes, we had to wait in traffic because of construction. We laughed when we saw big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument.

We saw many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park. There, we watched the sunset and saw bears. Sometimes, we had to stop for bears on the road. We had some exciting moments with bears and park rangers. 

As we drove, I forgot about home. The hotel we stayed in was old and did not have internet, but the views were beautiful. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we drove back home. My parents were right. You can find amazing things close to home. 

When we got home, I was happy to be with my family again. We took many photos of our trip. I knew I would remember the fun surprises we had on our journey.

**Simplified Text:**

Rose Frost was sixteen years old. She was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating. Her father, Jeff, had a job in another country, and her mother, Dahlia, would go with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy was finishing her last year of school. She had a nice room at her college with a kitchen and a study area. Amy could use the Internet and phone for free. Jeff and Dahlia would check on Amy, even if she did not like it.

Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She did not remember much about her grandmother, and she never knew her grandfather. Daisy wanted Rose to stay with her. Rose's parents were not happy about this, but Daisy was excited to see Rose again. Rose did not know why her parents did not like her grandma, but they had a fight a long time ago. Rose had not seen Daisy since she was ten years old, but she remembered happy times.

Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy liked to meet people and have fun. Rose thought she would get dinner invitations and go shopping with her grandma. This made her smile. Daisy was not a typical old lady. She went to many social events.

Before moving, Dahlia talked to Rose. Rose was sensible and knew about healthy eating and exercise. But she wanted to be independent. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission. She did not want to be told what to do all the time. Daisy understood this. 

Dahlia gave Rose a new mobile phone for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They all agreed to trust each other. Rose would act mature, and Daisy would not be too strict. If they had problems, they would talk about it.

Rose was not a wild child. She had good friends, and her school reports were always good. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school. This was her fourth school in five years, so she was used to it. She knew this would be her last school before finishing. For Rose, it was a new beginning in her life.

**Simplified Text:**

Charlotte Grainger had a teacher in primary school who thought she might write a book. Charlotte wanted to write a book because it seemed like a big challenge. When she turned 13, she decided to try. Now, her book is going to be published. She told her old teacher about it, and the teacher was surprised. The teacher thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40 years old. Charlotte did not understand why she should wait.

It is a winter afternoon in the office of Charlotte’s publishers. I was going to talk to a 15-year-old girl about her book. The book is very good. It has a strong story and a lot of action. You would not guess it was written by a teenager. A person from the publishing company is with us, but Charlotte does not need help. She is confident and smart, but she is also calm.

Charlotte knows she is young. I asked her about the big questions in her book. She said, “I was asking big questions, not answering them. I don’t have many life lessons to share.” She is interested in the idea of taking responsibility.

Charlotte thinks that books for teenagers often show three types of characters: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who has social problems. She does not like these types. She thinks there should be stories about teenagers who are okay and confident. She believes some writers make teenagers feel they do not know who they are, which can hurt their self-belief.

Charlotte loves to read books by famous fantasy writers, but sometimes these books made her not want to write. She thought, “Do I have to write like this to make a good book?” However, she liked a book called *How Not to Write a Novel*. It says that if the reader can guess what will happen, the story is not exciting anymore.

Charlotte’s parents are both journalists, and this helped her get her book published. Her father knew someone in publishing who read her book. She knows she is lucky because it is hard to get someone to read a first book. She says, “Every writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you are on your own. Writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I do not take anything for granted.” 

**Questions:**

1. Who thought Charlotte might write a book?
2. How old was Charlotte when she decided to write her book?
3. What does Charlotte think about the types of characters in books for teenagers?
4. What book helped Charlotte with her writing?
5. Why does Charlotte think she is lucky?

Text: 

"‘Remember, speed is good, not bad,’ said Gareth, our teacher, as we looked at the ski slope. ‘Who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then a guy named David, who had some experience with ski-jumping, went first. He skied down the slope towards the jump. He went fast and flew up into the air. We all held our breath. He landed hard, lost both skis, and fell into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said, ‘speed can be tricky.’ 

I thought maybe freestyle skiing was not for me. On other ski trips, I liked to practice turns in the snow. I was not like the teenagers who did tricks on ramps. I thought it looked fun, but I was scared to try. Then my parents took us to a training center for freestyle skiing in the US. It had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps with fake snow. Students jumped and tried new tricks, landing in foam cubes. This was not like skiing outside. 

After practicing inside, we went outside to try skiing for real. ‘You will get better!’ the center’s sign said. ‘Before places like this, new ski jumpers just went down the slopes and hoped for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you land on the flat part, you will get hurt.’ The flat part is called the ‘knuckle.’ If you land in the right place, you keep going. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, and it hurts. So, speed is important.

At first, I was scared to go fast. My legs wanted to stop as I got close to the jump, so I landed on the knuckle. I did not fall, but I felt tired. ‘You need to control the jump,’ said Gareth. 

On the second day, we practiced on the trampolines. I thought I would not like being inside, but bouncing was fun. Some exercises helped us learn how to jump. Gareth told us what to do. I needed to learn more about my body in the air. Every time I jumped, I only knew I was going up and then I found myself in the foam cubes.

We went back to the mountain to try again. I had some problems, but I finally landed well. Gareth was happy, and I felt proud. But on my last jump of the day, I went fast and landed in the right place. Then I saw my skis sliding down the slope, no longer on my feet."

Text: 

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster in a fun park. Your hands are sweaty, and you hold on tight. The ride stops, and you take a deep breath. Then, the carriage goes up slowly. There is a pause. Suddenly, it drops down, and your stomach feels funny. You go fast forward, then turn left, and then upside down. You feel scared and scream. But you chose to go to the fun park, like many other people do every year.

Fun parks are very popular. They have many exciting rides. Many people work hard to make these rides safe and fun. They are engineers, designers, and marketing experts. Some people dream of being rollercoaster designers when they are kids. But it is a big job. Designers must make the ride fun and safe. They also need to make new rides to keep people interested.

Many rollercoaster ideas were made a long time ago by a designer named John Miller. He made rides that were very exciting. Now, designers must follow rules and use special designs for rides. I talked to some experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a thrill engineer, said the skill is in putting everything together. Dr. John Roberts said it is important to make people feel excited but safe at the same time.

To make a great ride, designers create a story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase. They also think about how tall the ride is, how many twists it has, and how steep the drops are. Professor Walker said that experience and testing are very important. Jeff Hornick, a theme park director, said it helps to love thrills to understand what people want.

I asked if new technology, like virtual reality, will change rollercoasters. Walker said that while new technology is exciting, the real ride experience is still the most important part.

Text: 

Miranda Ellington is 25 years old. She is a choreographer. She makes dance shows for many theatres and dance groups. Sometimes, she still dances. I ask her why she does both things. She says, "Dancing helps me remember what it is like to be a dancer. It can be hard to take orders from choreographers." 

As a choreographer, Miranda teaches young dancers. She likes working with them. "Young dancers are open to new ideas. They want to learn and succeed. They may not know their strengths and weaknesses yet. They listen to my advice, even if it is tough. Sometimes, they ask questions, and I like their honest feedback."

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps. The music helps her decide what to do. "Sometimes, I don’t like a piece of music, but I still make a good dance for it. If dancers do not like the music, it can be hard, but I must find a way to help them. I wish I could try different music to make rehearsals better, but I usually work on big shows where the music is already chosen."

Miranda does not want to stay with one place. "I like to meet new people. But each theatre and school has different ways of working. I must change how I work each time I go somewhere new. This helps me not to get stuck in one way."

We talk about a new documentary about ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda says, "Some documentaries look nice but are not real. This one shows the true life in a dance company. There is a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections. I smiled because I understand her struggle. It is hard to watch, but it is real. People do not see how much work ballet takes."

I ask Miranda what makes a great dance show. She says, "It is when everything works well together – the music, costumes, lights, and dancers. We may not be perfect, but aiming high is good for the audience. Sometimes, the dance is good, but the costumes can be distracting, and that is disappointing."

Miranda has done many types of work. I ask if she is a modern dance choreographer or a ballet choreographer. She replies, "People want to label you, but I don’t understand why. I don’t want to be known for just one thing. For now, I want to learn and try new things."

Text: "A friend asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on TV. I said that TV shows many amazing things, but why stay at home when there is so much to see outside? This made me think of my fun four-day trip and a film to make people turn off their TVs. A friend was giving away his old sofa, and I used it in my film. I put three wheels and some cables on it and used old seatbelts to carry it. I put my bags on the sofa and slept on it at night, even one night on the beach. Some friends helped me pull the sofa and cheered me on. I have walked a lot in the past years, but this was very different. It was the longest I have ever walked, and I could stop at cafes and relax on the sofa with a drink instead of sitting on a rock. I often told people, “No, I am not doing this for charity, and I am not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I like to tell them how I pulled a sofa 100 miles in southern England instead of talking about TV shows. You can see the film on my website."

Text: "I read about swimming trips in the sea around small Greek islands. I was excited. I had never tried group trips before. My brother was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be good for me. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a ticket for one person. Many families go to the islands. I told him I would not be alone for long; I would join ten other people to swim around the small islands. He smiled and showed me on the boat.

Before we started, our group sent emails to each other, but we did not have much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides told us a support boat would help us, and they showed us how to talk to it. We swam a short distance to split us into speed groups. Then it was time for our first long swim of 1.5 km, and I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and swum in rivers, but I had never swum long distances in the sea.

Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this swim, and I was very happy when I did it by myself. The next days were the same: jumping in, swimming at a good speed, and stopping to look at the beautiful views. As the swims got longer, I swam faster and enjoyed it more. I did not need the support boat much. I can’t wait to come back next year."

Text: "Being a flight attendant is not easy, but it is fun. I have traveled to many places, like the US and Australia. I work with great people, I have free time, and my job is never boring. When I was a child, I went to a school far from my family. I flew alone to go to school and come back home. Sometimes, I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help them serve food to the passengers. Later, when I wanted a new job, I remembered this. 

At the job interview, there were many young people like me. They were also changing jobs. I practiced what to say before the interview. I talked about my skills and my past jobs, not just that I liked to travel. Because of this, I got the job! 

I think this job is good for many people. There are many good things about it, but free flights are not the best part. Most airline workers work very hard. There is a saying: 'No one is finished until everyone is finished.' It feels like a big family. Even if we do not see each other all the time, we are still close. When I am not working, I do not take work home. If I have a difficult passenger, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I will not see them again."

Text: "At the summer camp where I work, I like to see the children do well. Most children can swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel nervous, but with help, they try and reach the top. This makes them happy. 

At the start of the week, some children miss home. It is usually the children who are ten to thirteen years old. We do not let them use their mobile phones all the time. We tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again after dinner, we say it is too late to call now, and they can do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a few days. At the end of the week, they come to us and say thank you because they had a great time.

Sometimes, parents call a lot to ask about their child. This is not needed. Their child is often busy playing games or doing other things, so we tell the parents to call back later. We also see some children who wear expensive new clothes. These children sometimes argue when we ask them to change into other clothes, but soon they understand why."

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show. It opened in London last year. Before that, it was in the USA for five years. It won the ‘Best Musical’ award four times in the USA! 

In London, the show has all-British actors. This was hard because young actors in the UK can only do a few shows each week. In the USA, they can do more shows. So, they needed more actors in London. The director found many talented actors in the UK, and they won their first ‘Best Musical’ award.

The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA. It is full every night. Many people want to hear the songs from the show. I met Jamie, who is 11 years old and an actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s great that I get paid to play, especially with my beautiful Gibson guitar.’ 

Jamie told me that the young actors are very busy. They have school lessons at the theatre. He misses his old school friends. His whole class came to see the show. The theatre gives special ticket prices for schools. Jamie said his class loved the show, and this made him feel good. His parents come to see him when they can, but it is expensive for them.

When I said I also play guitar, Jamie found another guitar for me. We played a song called Days. I did not know this song, but Jamie helped me learn it. I was happy when I got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s skills. The young actors are already musicians, but none of them had played in a band before. They found it easy to play together. Jamie said the hard part was to look natural when they first performed. They were so focused that they forgot to smile!

The show will be in London for another year, and it is very good to see.'
